content.text:
The app appears to be decent with a good summary of information the phone and watch collect. The nutrition articles should be taken with a grain of salt. 

I took points off for their high-pressure sales tactics. I felt as if I was at an auto dealer being asked ‚Äúwhat can I do to get you in a car today.‚Äù

I subscribed to the app, checked it out, and the. Cancelled my subscription. It‚Äôs not worth the black-Friday sales price.

Since I cancelled my subscription, the app has thrown up a ‚ÄúProlong your Subscription‚Äù view and it doesn‚Äôt go away! (There was an ‚ÄúX‚Äù button but tapping did nothing.)

Time to ask for a refund.

content.text:
I subscribed to Gentler Streak for a year and really enjoyed some of the data. I did end up letting the subscription expire because I feel I have a better handle on my own training load now. On the positive, the app is well designed and I do feel like it was pretty decent at knowing when I needed to work vs rest, especially at first. However, once I got in a routine of regular workouts, it kept telling me to work harder to maintain my streak. Doing 30-60 minutes of strength training 3-4x per week and walking a lot seems like it should be plenty to keep me fit, but once Gentler Streak adapted to that routine, it started pushing me to do more and more in a way that felt unsustainable. 

I just returned from a 10-day trip to Europe, where we walked minimum 20K steps a day. I know the point of the app is to add more than just apple‚Äôs rings, but throughout that entire trip, the messages kept telling me to work out more and eventually ‚Äúlost‚Äù my streak. I don‚Äôt mind that of course, but it‚Äôs wild that it can‚Äôt consider that I was walking 10 miles a day. 

I also think it‚Äôs absurd that period tracking isn‚Äôt included in the free version. Feels like holding back an extra feature for 50% of the users.

Incomplete

content.text:
The app has a great looking UI and the functionality is exactly what I was looking to ensure that I am pushing the right amount during my trainings.
However it has 2 major flows that really really bother me.

1. The app does not sync on Strava or any other major "social fitness" platform. In 2024 this is really unacceptable. Everyone is connected and we like to maintain the social pressure as part of our motivation for working out. Just this flaw will translate in me not using Gentle Streak on the apple watch to track the runs, meaning that I am not able to use the great "body battery" indicator... 

2. The app is awesome to give you information on what to do today. It does not provide you with an upcoming plan for the week/month. That would be great to prepare properly and, if needed, organize the agenda accordingly. We are all busy and the possibility to prepare an adjustable plan will be more than welcome.

There are pros and cons in every app, but these 2 items (particularly #1) are so annoying that I wonder if I should maintain the subscription....

content.text:
This app seems like it's a stellar fitness app with how it encourages breaks and not overexerting, as opposed to the past few fitness apps I tried that seem to think that missing 1 calorie of my goal means I should run a triple marathon the next day. 

But every time I do a workout and adjust my RPE, the Activity Path on my phone and watch desync. It takes multiple reinstalls and restarts of my watch to fix this. Fixing an app's buggy behavior should not be part of my fitness routine!

title: What about all of my other activity?

content.text:
I love this app and I am a long time subscriber, but it misses a huge part of my physical activity.

As I‚Äôve seen in other reviews and in a support request, the developers dismiss the idea of using the data collected in Apple‚Äôs ‚ÄúMove‚Äù and ‚ÄúExercise‚Äù rings. Only tracked workouts are taken into account.

The app uses the Training Impulse (TRIMP) method to quantify the training load and stress placed on an athlete's body during exercise with the (admittedly) more accurate workout data.

However, ignoring all of the other physical activity that we do means that when we have an above average day of non-workout activity, the app‚Äôs recommendation is no different and it asks us to push too hard during our workouts.

The developers dig their heels in over not being able to use the less accurate non-workout data to determine the toll that this activity has on our bodies, but they already use: sleeping heart rate, sleep duration, wrist temperature, heart rate variability, respiratory rate, and oxygen saturation to estimate our overall wellbeing. These don‚Äôt fit anywhere in the TRIMP formula and are imperfect data that creates an imperfect estimate.

I appreciate the developers‚Äô goal of using a science and data backed approach to be sure that their app serves and protects us. I hope that they can find a way to bring the same rigor to expand the capability of the app to bring non-workout activity into the fold to provide a better picture of our workouts, overall activity, and recovery.

content.text:
I was hopeful this would track steps in real time vs. the health app that only updates periodically. I‚Äôm glad I read the reviews before purchasing the annual service. 

I get that they can‚Äôt track the impact to our bodies, but some of us use steps to track our movement in the day just in general and have other things we participate in that require steps tracking. 

It‚Äôs a shortcoming of this app to not have something as simple as a daily step count.

I‚Äôll update the stars for this app as I use it more.

It seemed over simplistic at first, but after using it for a few months it‚Äôs very effective at helping you stay on track while not overdoing it.

content.text:
The Activity Path is awesome. It considers all the data I‚Äôm shoving into Apple Heath with my smart devices and boils down into actionable context. It shows me the medium term (weeks) benefits of exercise and gives me short term (today) confidence in my activity decisions.

I‚Äôm currently using Gentler Streak alongside Runna, Oura and Apple Fitness. Gentler Streak provides a useful additional perspective on the data.

I tried the Go Gentler suggested workouts for a while. I found I usually wanted to work harder than it suggested. I still use it for informal things like active housework and chasing my kids at the playground, but I currently prefer Runna for structured training.

title: Like it a lot, but two major flaws for me

content.text: I like this app much more than others, even Apple's and I would actually become paid user, however there are two flaws that are too big for me to ignore. First of all, the AWU action button doesn‚Äôt start designated activity most of the time, it seems that this feature wasn‚Äôt properly tested before release. Second is dog walking activity, as it seems that they just renamed it and took all the parameters from walking one. Dog walking includes frequent stops, turns, sometimes even circles and the app is constantly nagging with activity seems to be stopped screen. If those two things are fixed in the near future, I will probably opt-in for paid version.

content.text: If I forget to end my walk, this app will keep on adding minutes to my time while I'm sitting still for 15 minutes or more. When I didn't "end" before I took my watch off & it went into Nightstand Mode, it added an 8 hour overnight walk. I know my Apple watch knows when I stop moving - I know there's a coder someplace who could fix this: don't know why the folks behind this app don't take the trouble to find one.

Gentler does help me keep being active because I have to log in the app what exercise I did. So at the moment it‚Äôs very pretty but kind of useless. I‚Äôll update my review if they can add a workaround for this other than ‚Äújust wait it out.‚Äù

I got the premium version as an alternative to the much pricier Visible Health subscription. I do love that Gentler Streak tells me when I'm pushing too hard, but it'd be awesome to have an option for saying I have a chronic illness that requires more days of rest that most people / a lower exertion threshold, a place to add in medications and conditions that impact HR, conditions that impact sleep and fatighe, etc.
Otherwise a great app! If you don't have an energy-limiting illness it's an excellent way to move more without the guilt.

content.text:
I‚Äôm not a competitive athlete. I‚Äôm an old fart and just want an app to help me stay healthy as long as possible. GS helps me stay motivated by tracking a few personal health and exercise metrics. I‚Äôve tried a bunch of the heavy hitters, but most of them are all about social media or flooded with ads. Gentler Streak is just about perfect for me. It track my bike rides, walks and stretching, yoga and strength training, encourages me when I‚Äôve been lazy for too long and even yells at me when I overdo it. I only wish it would read a few other metrics from Apple Health and display them along with the ones built into the ‚Äòwellbeing‚Äô tab, but I guess if they did that for everybody the app would end up being a bloated mess. Still, 95% perfect and (though I despise suckscriptions) Gentler Streak is one of the few I‚Äôll willingly pay.

** edit ** And congratulations on being recognized by Apple as a 2024 Design Award winner!

title: Gentler Streak falls short of expectations

content.text:
I subscribed to Gentler Streak for about a year, but I‚Äôve decided not to renew my subscription. Initially, I was drawn to the app because I thought its name suggested a focus on overall fitness goals in a balanced and supportive manner. However, my experience was quite different. The app frequently categorized my efforts as either over-reaching or slacking, which didn't align with my expectations for a "gentler" approach to fitness.

One aspect of the app that stands out positively is its feature to help you train during your menstrual cycle. While this is a thoughtful addition, it‚Äôs not relevant for me since I no longer have menstrual cycles.

In terms of performance, Gentler Streak does a decent job tracking cardio activities. However, it falls short when it comes to strength training. The app's capabilities in this area are lacking, which is a significant drawback if your fitness regimen includes a substantial amount of strength work.

That said, Gentler Streak could be beneficial if you are a runner training for marathons or races. The app seems well-suited for tracking and optimizing cardio efforts, making it a good companion for dedicated runners. 

Overall, while Gentler Streak has some merits, it doesn't quite meet my needs for a comprehensive fitness tracking app.

title: Great App but charges early adopters more

content.text:
I love this app and use it all the time. It is a great substitute for Whoop which costs $30/month

I usually keep a 5 star review for Gentler Streak, except that I am currently super disappointed that I am unable to signup with a Lifetime subscription. Apparently, since I‚Äôve been a subscriber since 2022, someone has decided that they should keep billing me every year and not allow me the option of a Lifetime subscription.

I cancelled my annual subscription renewal and have a few months to find a better option. Maybe after this years subscription runs out I‚Äôll be able to signup for the Lifetime option.

title: The App That Gets Me Moving

content.text: Gentler Streak does what many other apps try and fail to do: it gets me moving. Most health apps (especially nutrition apps) are bloated and ask all sorts of questions I have no desire to engage with (hello ‚ÄúWhat‚Äôs your goal weight?‚Äù). But Gentler Streak has distilled an important part of daily movement down to the essentials. And it has helped me form a contract with myself. Every day I have the opportunity to wake up and promise to myself that I‚Äôll do my best to do a little more today than I did yesterday. And that simplicity is powerful.

title: It‚Äôs not just about PACE‚Ä¶it‚Äôs about peace of mind!

content.text:
The "Gentler Streak" fitness app encourages a self-compassionate approach to exercise and provides a balance between fitness and rest. It offers personalized suggestions for daily workout actions, which can range from rest to intense workouts. It helps me - a 67 year old guy who values a balanced approach to fitness and well-being - stay within healthy activity levels. 

With an intuitive UI, it‚Äôs so easy to use, even my grandma could do it‚Äîand she can‚Äôt tell a smartwatch from her headstone. It‚Äôs easy to understand and won‚Äôt leave you sweating the small stuff.

The app‚Äôs feedback is so encouraging, it‚Äôs like having a cheerleader in your pocket. It‚Äôll lift your spirits higher than a kettlebell! 
Additionally, the app provides relevant, actionable insights and expert knowledge in short reads.

title: No trial period for most features.

content.text: I was really excited to use this app, since I frankly find the Apple Health app unusable in terms of understanding metrics, but I was super disappointed because basically all of the features are locked behind the paywall. To be clear, I‚Äôm not against paying for an app that works and is genuinely helpful, but if I can‚Äôt see what I‚Äôm paying for, then why should I spend any money? They advertise a 48-hour promotion to buy an annual subscription‚Ä¶ why not give us a 48-hour trial to even see if it‚Äôs worth it?

content.text: There was a time in my life when I was an Ironman triathlete, but a combination of COVID, heavy workload and aging had my fitness levels drop significantly over recent years. Gentler Streaks has been fantastic in helping me to get back into shape, giving me a supportive and *gentle* push to gradually increase my activity without wearing myself out or yo-yo‚Äôing into and out of cycles of exercise. The interface is great and easy to follow, the technical side of the app is excellent, and the feedback is fun. I use this app everyday and find it to be a great compliment to Apple Fitness+.

title: Pretty App to Designed to Keep You On the Sofa

content.text:
It‚Äôs a cute app, and I love the concept. 

However, I am accustomed to 2-3 workouts a week. These vary intensity. My Apple Watch says my cardio fitness is ‚Äúabove average‚Äù and I feel I have normal recovery times. I‚Äôm far from a fitness junky, but like average fit I‚Äôd say. 

I just came back to logging after taking a break (but not a break from working out) and gentler streak tells me my 27 minute gentle Pilates session (my heart rate was in zones ‚Äú0‚Äù and ‚Äú1‚Äù according to Gentler puts me into ‚Äúover exertion‚Äù. That going for a slow walk for the morning after is ‚Äútoo much‚Äù. 

If you want an app that congratulates you for doing a singular workout and gives you an excuse to ‚Äúrest‚Äù for days after any moderate effort ‚Ä¶ Sign on up. If you actually want something to give you insights on your health and fitness and encourages you to improve, move along.

title: BEST workout tracker !!! With one request

content.text:
I ADORE this app!! I have a pretty bad tendency to push myself too hard when I workout, and this app has helped me so much to always have an idea of where my body is at and if I need to back off. It helps me stay on track and lets me know when I need to get a workout in (wouldn‚Äôt want to lose my streak of course). I especially love that the messages are written like a friend encouraging you to stay with it and keep going without being harsh or feeling shameful. 

The one feature that would make this so much better is if there was a notes section inside each activity after they‚Äôve been completed. When you open the activities tab and select a recently completed activity, I imagine that there could be a ‚Äúnotes‚Äù section under ‚Äúcharts‚Äù and ‚Äúperceived exertion.‚Äù I usually record my workouts as ‚Äústrength training‚Äù but have a tendency to forget when the last time was that I worked a certain muscle group. As a college student I can‚Äôt always go to the gym consistently so I get workouts in when I can. This means I don‚Äôt have a set weekly workout schedule and must try to remember the last time I hit legs lol. Having a section for notes would make it so much easier to remember when I did certain workouts, or it could even be used as a way to track weight and reps for the day. I‚Äôve been trying to find a way to track these things either on my own or in an app and it just doesn‚Äôt seem like anything exists for this purpose and/or is easy to use. In addition to a notes section, it could be helpful to be able to add a title or subtitle to an activity to more easily identify details about it. This could look like ‚Äústrength training - Legs‚Äù where the original title of the activity remains, but you are able to add quick details to the log. 
I already love this app so much and use it for every workout, but if this feature could be added my love for gentler would just grow even more. I think it would really enhance the already amazing experience and make workout tracking that much easier.

title: Great for Novice, not great for serious training

content.text:
I love that Gentler Streak makes it simple and easy for folks who are just beginning their fitness journey. However, if you are a serious athlete training for a marathon, 15 K, or some other endurance race this is probably not the app for you. I have been training for eight weeks and recently completed a 8 mile run. I took a day off to recover, and then the following day the app said I was pushing too hard, 1 mile in to a 2 mile active recovery run. I know my body and I know when it is time to lay off. Being in tune with my body and whether or not, it‚Äôs ready after recovery is something that comes with years of training and experience.

Again, this is great for those just beginning, or just wanting to learn about their body and it‚Äôs response to stress from physical activity. It is not meant for rigorous and experienced endurance athletes.

content.text:
Context: 66 yrs female. 
Never been athletic or get a charge from achieving goals or competitive games. I‚Äôm past my ‚Äúprime‚Äù as they say. I am constantly managing the possibility of inducing a migraine after exercise. However, the truth is that not exercising feeds depression, arthritis, dementia, insomnia, osteoporosis, dullness, and weight gain. 
Go Gentler has been my friend and coach while I navigate staying fit. I found this Go Gentler app after I purchased the expensive Apple Watch (which was a great investment!). Coupling the app with Apples Health Tracker has been so helpful to assess my ups and downs and to stay positive about myself.

title: Stop comparing activity to food consumed

content.text:
I enjoy this app, but I can‚Äôt recommend it to a friend who would love it because you compare calories burned to food. She has an eating disorder, and if you won‚Äôt take this feature off the app altogether, it should at least be something you can turn off.

Its harmful to think about movement this way. If this app is meant to be gentler, then we need to motivate movement for our wellbeing, not to counteract what we put in our bodies to stay alive.

content.text: In my opinion, this app doesn‚Äôt really measure activity well; it frequently tells me I‚Äôm over reaching to the point where I don‚Äôt even log workouts‚Äîa thirty minute walk plus 30 minutes of yoga is not over reaching, at least not for me. I get that for some people it might be, but with my current fitness levels and history of amount of time working out, the app should know after three months that this is a normal amount of activity for me. I guess if you want to be very, very gently coaxed into doing a bit more activity, this app will work, but if you want to challenge yourself and if you‚Äôre already fairly active, I‚Äôd suggest looking elsewhere.

title: This is the BEST health, wellness, and fitness tracker I‚Äôve ever used

content.text:
I became aware of this app at the beginning of 2023 after searching for one to help me with my New Year resolution. I wanted to assess better when to work out and which type I‚Äôll do for each day. 

Each morning, this app helps me improve my self-care because of the metrics it provides about my previous night. I tried the one-week free trial before purchasing my annual subscription. Over the last year, I followed the Gentler Streak recommendation, and it has helped improve my wellness overall. 

I realized I was pushing too hard during some workouts and was not well enough to exercise on other days. Recommended rest days were always impactful. 

I encourage anyone who wishes to improve their self-care more compassionately to start the same journey I did with this app. You won't regret it.

I basically never write reviews but this app deserves it. I have used this app for just under one year. I struggled a lot with finding time for exercise both because of busy schedules and mental health. This app allowed me to feel good about even little accomplishments and helped me get the momentum to keep trying. There‚Äôs a break/sick/vacation option that‚Äôs the major bonus over apple health/rings because you don‚Äôt feel awful if you need to take time to heal. Highly recommended!!

title: A perfect alternative to Apple Fitness

content.text:
I love the personalized approach to fitness on this app! I still use my Apple Watch activity app to track my workouts since it‚Äôs what I‚Äôm familiar with, but I love that the two apps talk to each other back and forth so I can go into gentler streak and see my heart rate zones and understand when I might be overdoing it. 

A way way way more personal and maintainable approach to fitness, that doesn‚Äôt require you to set any unrealistic goals that you won‚Äôt stick with, and doesn‚Äôt focus on weight loss/calories.

title: After searching for over a decade‚Ä¶

content.text: This is the only workout app that has made me want to work out. The fact that it counts rest days as productive and encourages you not to lose your streak in a gentle way, is the best! Other apps are just about checking something off or marking it done, and when you miss one, you feel terrible. This gives you flexibility and as long as you‚Äôre in the progress zone, you‚Äôre good! Also love it talks to the health app, so if I‚Äôm doing a workout with another app that talks to the health app, Gentle Streak marks it too. Love love love this app!

title: Don‚Äôt use if you‚Äôre interested in increasing fitness

content.text: This app is not for anyone looking to improve their fitness level. Any time I actually exercise, it cries at me or chastises me and calls me an overachiever. And I mean, if all I do is a slow 3 mile jog or a moderate 30 minute strength training session, it gives me grief. The only days I don‚Äôt get chewed out by this app are days that I am not exercising. I tried it for two months to see if I could figure out how to increase my fitness activity without it whining at me or complaining, and I never could. Deleting. Waste of money.

title: I love this app! Two wishes‚Ä¶

content.text:
As a long-time endurance athlete, it‚Äôs easy to get sucked into comparison. My friend did this, I‚Äôm falling behind. Oh, my run today was really slow, I need to make an excuse in my Strava workout description so people have context and don‚Äôt think poorly of me. It‚Äôs more exhausting than the actual long runs. 

Gentler is the perfect antidote. Instead of obsessing over what other people are doing or the optics of what I‚Äôm doing, I can focus on what my body needs. Novel idea in the age of social media! Plus it still has the data I need to train effectively, unlike many ‚Äúalternative‚Äù exercise tracking apps. 

Also love that the nutrition and exercise tips are rooted in science, not diet culture. Whole posts about how beneficial carbs and fat are? Major green flag üíö

I only have two complaints, and these are missing features/opportunities rather than broken current ones. 

1. I wish there was better integration for folks not using an Apple Watch. I have a very nice GPS watch with the battery life needed for running ultras, so no intention of ever switching to an Apple Watch.

Unfortunately, I run into barriers with this app, like not being able to use or even view the suggested Gentler workouts. I wish there was a way to export them to Coros, or even just look at their details in the app so I can manually program a workout on my watch (or at least know what to shoot for).

2. I wish I could edit activities, especially activity types, within the Gentler app. Once an activity is exported from my watch to the app, I can‚Äôt edit the type. 

So for example, since my watch doesn‚Äôt have a specific yoga mode and I use the ‚Äúgym cardio‚Äù mode, Gentler views my yoga activities as weightlifting (or other), and I can‚Äôt change it. Same goes for trail running, mountain biking, etc. Gentler offers those as supported activities types but I wish I could change my already imported workouts to those supported types like is possible in Strava.

It‚Äôs not the end of the world, but when viewing monthly and yearly data, I‚Äôd love to be able to differentiate between days I actually lifted weights and when I did yoga, or how many times I rode my mountain bike versus road bike.

At the end of the day, pretty minor things that won‚Äôt keep me from using the app, but I think it would take the overall user experience to a new level!

Thank you for making an app for recovering comparison addicts like myself. It‚Äôs really helpful for reframing my fitness journey and helping me focus on the activity and how it benefits my body instead of how it looks to others.

content.text: The app in question was a textbook example of a subpar user experience. Its interface was cluttered and confusing, making it a challenge to navigate and find the desired features. The app frequently crashed, leaving users frustrated and often unable to complete even the most basic tasks. To add to the frustration, it bombarded users with intrusive and irrelevant ads, disrupting the overall usability. Furthermore, customer support was virtually non-existent, making it nearly impossible to address any issues or seek assistance. In sum, the app's poor design, constant crashes, and lack of support made it an infuriating and overall unpleasant experience for users.

title: Loved until the watch app stopped working

content.text:
Update: 
My watch just aged out of the app. If you have a newer Apple Watch, it should work great for you. Huge bummer that my otherwise perfectly functional device will no longer support this app that I used all day everyday but I guess maybe I can get back into regular use when I am able to afford a new watch ü§∑üèª‚Äç‚ôÄÔ∏è. Better than the Apple fitness rings if it works on your Watch. 

Original review:
I started paying for this app earlier this year and absolutely loved it for the first half of 2023. After an update about a month ago, maybe longer, the watch app totally stopped working then disappeared from my watch. I have tried redownloading to my watch periodically since incase it is fixed by a subsequent update and every time I am told the download failed and to try again later. Anyone else having this problem? I really loved the app so I hope it is resolved quickly.

title: After a full week of resting I‚Äôm still ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù

content.text:
I don‚Äôt know what the intent behind this app is, because all it seems to say is that I‚Äôm overreaching. I took two short (10 min ea) bike rides and it said I was overreaching for a day before telling me to exercise. Then I took one long bike ride (2 hrs) a week ago and today it still says I‚Äôm overreaching and need to rest. I haven‚Äôt even taken walks since then! If you want to build your fitness level go find an app that will actually push you. If you want to feel good about being lazy download this app. 

 Edit: I just got a message that I need to log a workout (even though I just did one yesterday) and it STILL says I‚Äôm overreaching.

Edit 2: I didn‚Äôt open it for a couple weeks and the widget said for all of that time that I was either well rested or overreaching. It never said I was on the right track and it took days to go from overreaching to the well rested, never stopping in the middle. Then today I got a mea culpa message when I opened the app saying their onboarding was messed up and they were going to fix that. Near as I can tell nothing has been fixed. Go find another app, this one is not good.

content.text: Generally a good app, good advice and creates a useful record, but one BIG problem.  The problem is that sometimes I inadvertently hit a button on my watch and the app records a workout that becomes a permanent part of my record though nothing really happened.  I need the ability to edit and tweak the records created to make sure they properly reflect what I actually did.  Without that, the records are faulty and not nearly so useful as the app would like to make me think they are.
content.html:
Problem

Generally a good app, good advice and creates a useful record, but one BIG problem. The problem is that sometimes I inadvertently hit a button on my watch and the app records a workout that becomes a permanent part of my record though nothing really happened. I need the ability to edit and tweak the records created to make sure they properly reflect what I actually did. Without that, the records are faulty and not nearly so useful as the app would like to make me think they are.

title: Needs sleep tracking and sleep alarm

content.text:
For this price point, I wish we had a tab for seeing most recent and older sleep results, along with note taking and adding tags for both our sleep and workouts to later come back to and see "oh I tagged 'sunny' for these workouts and sleep data, maybe that's why I ---"

But also adding a customizable alarm for either watch, phone or iPad, or all of them with an adjustable 15-30 minute wake window for smooth wakening, and multiple smooth alarm options. Just as Sleep Cycle has done.

title: Ridiculous and discouraging feedback from app

content.text:
I‚Äôve used the app over two months and found if anything it has a negative impact on my physical health and the statements about my health just piss me off. I spent a week on vacation walking and hiking in the mountains. Even on light days that I considered no exertion the app screamed at me that I was overdoing it. After returning home and not exercising for 2 days it was still threatening that dire things would happen if I didn‚Äôt rest. Then I wake this morning to it flipping 180 over night and now telling me my fitness is in decline from not exercising! Sadly, inaccurate, alarming, and wildly extreme comments like this are normal for this app. 
The flip flopping and inaccuracy of the comments makes this worthless. Wish I hadn‚Äôt spent money on it but the free/trial version was too pared down to know what it does. Going back to just using apple fitness, it actually reflects what I do in a day whether I start it tracking or not.

title: The right way to be (re)introduced to fitness

content.text:
Gentler Streaks makes fitness accessible to all. It lowers the barrier to entry (your own mind!) and does so in a fun and delightful way. As someone who has always had a complicated relationship with fitness and who has tried lots of apps to track workouts or provide motivation, this one is by far the best.

Gentler Streaks combines the tracking necessities with the appropriate motivation to help you continually achieve your fitness goals. No matter if you‚Äôre a novice runner or an expert powerlifter, there‚Äôs something in this app for you. It‚Äôll tell you when it‚Äôs time to give your body a break and when it‚Äôs time to push to the next level.

The added benefit of Wellbeing, which utilizes sleep tracking data, is something I have yet to explore as I don‚Äôt sleep with my watch on, however I‚Äôm considering adding that to my routine since I‚Äôm so happy with the rest of the functionality in this app.

Love to see the continued updates being pushed frequently and Gentler Streaks getting better and better. Keep up the great work. üèãüèª

title: Don‚Äôt use Apple health vo2 max to assess fitness.

content.text:
Gentler streak is using Apple health‚Äôs Vo2max assessment to plot an activity path, unfortunately Apple‚Äôs vo2max assessment doesn‚Äôt take into consideration the fact that when I hike I‚Äôm walking steep mountain trails, carrying a heavy pack, and so it assumes I‚Äôm far less fit than I am. 
That breaks the deal for me, either be accurate or I‚Äôm not interested.

title: Not worth it if you don‚Äôt have an Apple Watch

content.text: I love the idea, but you really need an Apple Watch to make it work. In theory, it‚Äôs supposed to work as long as all your data is in the apple health app. But if you don‚Äôt have a fitness tracker, or your tracker is a Fitbit, all your data isn‚Äôt going to be in the apple health app, and then it‚Äôs not going to do much for you. (There are separate 3rd party apps that sync Fitbit with AH, but they all seem sketchy - personally I don‚Äôt like to give out my data like that.) You have to pay to be able to add things to Gentler Streaks manually, and even then it keeps displaying things about fitness trackers, like telling you to wear your smartwatch to bed. They should really make it clear up front that 99% of the functions are based on having an Apple Watch.

title: Great premise, very slow to load ü´§

content.text:
I really love the concept of the app, but it is incredibly slow to open and load data (noticeably slower than other data intensive apps). If I‚Äôm trying to get a quick sense of where I‚Äôm at in the day this is often enough delay that I just close the app and move on. If I open a month in review, it has to process the data again it seems, even if I‚Äôve looked at the month before.

I like that the app helps focus on relative effort, and encourages you to get back into things, well, gently. It‚Äôs so much nicer than apps that don‚Äôt afford any rest time or that don‚Äôt account for overall wellness when setting goals and determining steaks.

I‚Äôll keep with it for now at least!

content.text:
I expected a lot more out of a $30 app. The rest tracker is interesting and what drew me into the app, but I wouldn‚Äôt have paid $30 if I knew that was essentially all it was.

The data it tracks can already be tracked via your apple watch, fitness, and health app. The rest of the content is pretty worthless as well. It‚Äôs a bunch of regurgitated summaries of fitness articles. 

I could maybe see this being helpful if you are 100% new fitness but the app doesn‚Äôt offer much else if you‚Äôre already on your fitness journey. 

Beyond the rest tracker you‚Äôre basically paying $30/year to reskin the fitness and health app that already comes on your phone.

title: An app that finally validates my daily movements.

content.text:
At my current job, I end up walking between 14k-24k steps (~7-12 miles) in a singular 5-10 hour shift. It‚Äôs exhausting both physically and mentally, and there‚Äôs obviously no point in me trying to add in an ‚Äúofficial‚Äù walk/run exercise on any of the days that I‚Äôm working.

I was a bit hesitant to try this app out after reading a handful of reviews that talked about how they ‚Äúwished the activity path would include daily steps‚Äù in it‚Äôs calculations. Obviously, the only metric I‚Äôm actually measuring while at work IS, in fact, my daily step count, alongside occasional heart rate readings and ‚Äúidle‚Äù exercise minutes (~60-150min total) that get tracked outside of official workouts.

DAILY STEPS DO HAVE AN EFFECT ON THE ACTIVITY PATHWAY!

I don‚Äôt know how many daily steps those other reviewers were counting, but I can see a major difference in my activity path between the 4 days that I work 9-10 hours, the day I work 5 hours, and the 2 days I get off during the week. The difference is blatantly obviously when you move as much as I do during a work shift.

This app really makes me feel validated in my physical fitness. I can‚Äôt begin to tell you how many times I would come home from work and think to myself something along the lines of, ‚ÄúYou shouldn‚Äôt be this tired. You‚Äôre not doing much of anything worth feeling tired over.‚Äù But this app is the first thing to tell me that I‚Äôm pushing myself hard, that I‚Äôm edging towards the limits of my physical capabilities, that I should take a day to rest and recover (which I sadly can‚Äôt because it‚Äôs my job).

The ‚ÄúGo Gentler‚Äù workouts are also really nice. I really like the interface on the Apple Watch and how it shows you your HR zones as the default screen during an exercise. (I know Apple‚Äôs Exercise app supposedly has a screen for HR zones too but I can‚Äôt figure out how to show that while exercising.)

I think my one recommendation/request for this app going forward would be the ability to customize the ‚ÄúGo Gentler‚Äù workouts, which doesn‚Äôt seem to be an option as far as I can tell. Apple‚Äôs Exercise app lets you set up custom workouts with intervals, repetitions, and has the option for warmup and cooldown times. If there was a way to do that with the ‚ÄúGo Gentler‚Äù workouts too, I think this app would be nearing perfection.

So it‚Äôll literally suggest I go take an outdoor bike ride for 5 min if I ask it to adjust to a lower ‚Äúlevel‚Äù. Really?! I thought it would be much more informative. And even giving me some sort of workout plan. I also thought it would directly me whether i *should* rest or push. Training today app is much better on this front of telling me by my biometrics if my body should rest. Def won‚Äôt buy again.

content.text:
I just subscribed for a year because I love the iPhone app and the metrics. I also like the design of the workout screens on the watch, but the performance has been really bad. 
The running workout auto-pause takes like 2min to realize you have stopped, and if I decide to pause manually, the app crashes and I lose all of the GPS tracking before the app froze. Totally unreliable metrics. Going to stick with the Apple workouts for now‚Ä¶
Also, I wish there were more settings available for the watch app, like heart rate (audio) alerts. Couldn‚Äôt find that.

title: Still needs a bit of work

content.text:
UPDATE: We still aren‚Äôt getting anything to show our steps as activity in this app. That‚Äôs a critical issue here. We shouldn‚Äôt have to log our daily steps as workouts to record the activity. I‚Äôve tried doing this to have a more accurate picture of wellbeing and actually have the app saying I‚Äôm overreaching when it‚Äôs not that hard to walk throughout the day, taking breaks in between. Developers need to find a way to work this into the algorithm for the app. As it stands it seems that while other apps ignore the need for customization based on individual abilities/needs this app ignores the need to have basic data at its core. We need to meet somewhere in the middle here ASAP. 
‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî‚Äî
I like the app but there are area it needs work; 1) The new Wellbeing tab and syncing with Health is good, but why doesn‚Äôt it show our steps? and why aren‚Äôt our streaks reflecting our walking throughout the day? This needs attention ‚ÄºÔ∏è 2) I‚Äôve had to edit sleep in other apps as it over estimated my time sleeping. But then this app shows ‚ÄúInsufficient data‚Äù under the Wellbeing tab.ü§® The day is there? I just corrected it so that the record is accurate. This shouldn‚Äôt be a problem. 3) One of the reasons I‚Äôve liked this app is the ability to do things at our own pace. I don‚Äôt like the ‚Äúreminders‚Äù about exercising or losing a streak. A streak shouldn‚Äôt rely solely on workouts but also steps. See point 1.

title: Great app! Could be even better.

content.text:
I love the concept and the delivery of this app. I appreciate being able to take a pause and tweak settings so I can prevent disordered eating triggers and I can modify the level of rigor of the app. I love the positivity and that I feel like I can come back after an illness or rough mental health week. I also love that it takes my physical health into consideration helps me keep an eye on my metrics. I can even tell when I don‚Äôt use my CPAP machine for a night, which keeps me motivated to use the machine!

Features I would love to see, as a currently subscribed user: - Goals. I don‚Äôt always have time or energy to work out daily, but I‚Äôm not ‚Äúsick‚Äù or ‚Äúon a break‚Äù. Streaks (the app that inspired this app) allows me to adjust the timeframe that I complete my goals, such as 3x per week. In Gentler Streaks, I‚Äôd love to be able to set my fitness goals at 3x per week and then if I fall behind, the app lets me know if I need to ‚Äústep up my game.‚Äù - Ability to modify messages. I would like to be able to change the text, for instance where it says ‚ÄúStep up your game.‚Äù Making the app more customizable would be better for everyone, no matter the desired level of rigor. Adding these features would make this a 5-star app.

title: The best fitness app out there and the only one that doesn‚Äôt punish you for rest

content.text:
I‚Äôve tried multiple fitness apps but none of them really stuck. Gentler Streaks is different. It helps keep me motivated while also giving me permission to rest when I need it. I find seeing my Activity Path slowly rise up gives me concrete evidence that I‚Äôm improving and motivates me further to keep things going.  

When using it on the Apple Watch, it functions very similar to Apple‚Äôs native workout app. This I like, because I enjoy the setup of Apple‚Äôs workout app and ease of use. However, unlike Apple, it offers you the chance to change your status from active to injured, sick, or on a break. This is what sets it apart because with Apple and other fitness apps, if you lose one day you‚Äôre punished for it by losing your streaks, even if you‚Äôre injured or sick. Gentler Streaks understands that you shouldn‚Äôt be punished for being injured, sick, or simply on vacation. Everyone needs a break sometimes and when you want to start things up again, you can switch back to ‚Äúactive‚Äù and Gentler Streaks will give you a fitness plan that won‚Äôt burn you out or cause you to reinjure yourself.  

There are two recommendations I would give to make this app even better.

The first is that I wish there was a better way to see your progress over time. You get a monthly and yearly recap, but I‚Äôd like the option to look at my Activity Path and see how it changes over time whenever I want to. You see the past ten days, and like I said before seeing the difference does help motivate me, but I‚Äôd like to zoom out a little further whenever I wanted to.   

The second is that I‚Äôd love to see more articles/insights! There‚Äôs a good selection right now, but I love reading these articles and learning more about how I can improve. As a copywriter though, I understand how long it can take to cobble an article together so I understand why there aren‚Äôt more right now :)

As a copywriter though, I understand how long it can take to cobble an article together so I understand why there aren‚Äôt more right now :)

content.text:
Update: I‚Äôve had this app 4+ months now and still do not see the value. I do not plan to renew my subscription and do not think it is worth the cost. 

Things that don‚Äôt make sense to me and could use improvement:
- you can only see the last 10 days of your activity path (so you cannot see long term improvements or decline in activity)
- any activity that you do that is not logged as a workout does not affect your activity path
- many (all?) workouts logged through this app seem to count 100% toward your exercise ring (rather than only counting walking that is brisk enough)
- per the previous two points, if I log 90 min. of ‚ÄúDaily Chores‚Äù so that my activity for the day is reflected in this app, it counts as 90 min. of exercise in my apple health app
- the wellness tab and the activity path don‚Äôt work well together. I‚Äôve had days where the wellness tab tells me to take it easy but the activity path tells me I need to step it up or I‚Äôm going to fall off my activity path

Initial Review: I‚Äôve been subscribed for at least a couple of months now. I have yet to see the real value this provides beyond the workout tracking that is available and built into the Apple Watch. I am intrigued to see how the Wellness tab possibly enhances this app. BUG: The sleep info in the wellness tab is incorrect. It seems you are only pulling in the sum of the stages of sleep. For example, my health app says I slept 8h 48m but your app says 6h 34m.

content.text: I purchased this app on sale as I was searching for something to manage stress and ran across this app. So far, it‚Äôs been great tracking my stats. I love seeing my numbers in an easy to follow graph and it is always spot on when telling me perhaps I need to rest. Each time I have been feeling sluggish or unwell, the app ‚Äúknows‚Äù based on my data. This has helped me take it easy when I otherwise would continue to push myself just because of my Type A personality. The app gives me the reassurance to listen to my body and put my well-being first. I absolutely love the app!

This is an excellent app. When I first installed it I thought it just based its recommendations on workouts alone. Turns out, it bases it on pretty much every important metric your watch tracks.

With this it calculates if you‚Äôre ready to take it to the next level, or rest. At first, it often told me to rest. Months later, it often tells me I‚Äôm in great shape to push myself. It‚Äôs such a satisfying part of my fitness journey

title: Neat App But Seems to Lack Accuracy

content.text:
This is a great app. I love the way the information is laid out. I love the design a lot. I only have two gripes. 

1. For context, I wear an Apple Watch Ultra almost 24/7. I am in good health. I‚Äôm a long distance trail runner. I spend a lot of time on my feet every week. I‚Äôm not fast, but I do speedwork (whatever that is for a 49 year old) about once per week. Go Gentler doesn‚Äôt seem to take into account current fitness levels or heart rate data. It seems to be mostly based on time. I could do a slow two hour run, and it will push me into the ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù zone even though I‚Äôm in zone 2 most of the time. Then I do a ‚Äúfast‚Äù 5k, and it barely registers as a workout. I may be more tired from the 5k, but the app is telling me to do more. Not correct. I‚Äôve used other apps (e.g., Athlytic) that handle the data better. 

2. If you use the track bar graph instead of the single line, it constantly moves and tries to show you how you can ‚Äúsneak‚Äù ahead into the future. I get it. I got it the first time. Don‚Äôt show me that and give haptic feedback *every single time,* please. I switched to the single line because it was so annoying. 

I paid for an annual subscription because overall, I do love the app. But I hope to see improvements.

title: Excellent job on the health Metrics

content.text: I've had to revise my earlier five star review because of an issue with the new Metrics and Sleep. The app is constantly under measuring the sleeve, showing in the health app by as much as two hours I have reported this to support and one of the latest version says the problem has been fixed, but it hasn't. Until the sleep issue is fixed the metrics are unusable for me. Sorry to say I don't know what else to do.

content.text:
It‚Äôs definitely a healthier approach than apple‚Äôs ‚Äúclose your rings everyday‚Äù approach. I bought the annual subscription and use the widget to keep keep an eye on my zones throughout the week. It‚Äôs a newer app, so I‚Äôm sure there‚Äôs a lot of great features on the way. After using it for few months here are my notes for improvement: 1. The app almost always says I‚Äôm overreaching. I‚Äôve been working out 3x a week for one hour each morning doing moderate - intense weight training g. This has been my routine for months and it still says I‚Äôm pushing too hard. Perhaps add a way to adjust zones or customize it based on goals. 2. The zones seem arbitrary. As a user I have absolutely no clue how the graph is calculated or how the data I‚Äôm plugging in actually impacts future projections. Adding some reading material for us to reference that gets into the nitty gritty aspects of your algorithm would be helpful. 3. Analyze past Apple Health data/ allow back scrolling by more than 10 days. This might already be done, but that‚Äôs not apparent. Another benefit would include automatically giving personalized zones. 4. Minor but an Apple Watch-style ring closing notifications that tell me if I‚Äôm on track would be neat. I originally switched to replace that feature. Overall this is a great app and the UI is on point. The algorithm discourages pushing myself to the point of it almost being negative (coincidentally this leads me to ignore the ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù alerts). However I feel it‚Äôs taught me to listen to my body more. I‚Äôm excited to see what your team has in store!

UPDATE
I appreciate the response. I have been using my Apple Watch for 18 months consistently, and gradually increased my workout with a personal trainer. Therefore the ‚Äúoverworking‚Äù algorithm appears to have bugs (cited by others, not just me.)
Since writing the review I have decided to switch back to Apple‚Äôs native health app. While the daily rings isn‚Äôt ideal, it offers a more robust analysis of my workout patterns. I look forward to trying Gentler Streak in the future when some more features have been added!

title: Pretty, supportive, but based on science?

content.text:
First, the app is visually appealing and offers positive support & encouragement for health & fitness goals. But I‚Äôm not sure if the goals/guidance it gives you are based on science or‚Ä¶ what, biorhythms? There used to be this range of effort that would fluctuate up and down over time, with the app encouraging you to stay within that zone, but I don‚Äôt know what that zone was based on. 

Next, I subscribed for a year because it seemed useful, but without the specific explanation for what that zone was based on, it‚Äôs hard to be reassured that it actually meant something. Then after I let my subscription end, they tweaked the app so that zone is no longer visible at all - meaning that the free version just offers encouragement without anything more concrete. I let my sub lapse but I didn‚Äôt delete the app; after this change, I don‚Äôt see any reason to keep it anymore.

content.text:
Love the idea of the app! I think the devs are some really great people who want to bring a quality app to the App Store. I love the idea of this app, but it sometimes doesn‚Äôt live up to its expectations. 

A suggestion: give us the option to manually override the results of the ‚Äúwell-being‚Äù section. It keeps saying I‚Äôm not well prepared for the day and gives me a frowny face even though I‚Äôve hit all of my sleep metrics except for one. That really doesn‚Äôt necessitate a frowny face and a ‚Äúfocus on wellbeing‚Äù message. Why not? content.text:
Update:  I uninstalled this app after several months. While I commend the app developers for offering to give away licenses to those who are unable to pay the subscription, I don‚Äôt feel it‚Äôs the right thing to do to take advantage of such an offer.

Really, this should be a cheaper one-time purchase instead of soaking people for a subscription as so many other app developers do these days.

This app is worthless in free mode. With other similar excellent one-time purchase apps like Personal Best out there, I just can‚Äôt fathom paying what the developers want for this.

Original review below‚Ä¶

I have several really good fitness apps that I rely on. All charge a low one-time price for use. While this app looks like it will be a lot of fun to add to my routine, I can‚Äôt afford yet another subscription app. I wish developers would stop this practice

title: No idea why this was the app of the year üôÑ

content.text:
I‚Äôll fully admit I ain‚Äôt perfect and this could be user error and me failing to understand the app, but I find it completely useless and I‚Äôm very disappointed that I spent 30-odd doll hairs on something that is basically a daily reminder. I love the idea of having rest days in your health maintenance routine, but this ain‚Äôt it. 

Go Gentler doesn‚Äôt measure my activity the same way my watch does and it‚Äôs frustrating. It only counts what i log as a workout or do on Meta. For example, on a trip to NYC I  walked over 25K steps four days in a row, like LONG outdoor walls that I don‚Äôt count as a workout, but IT‚ÄôS STILL EXERCISE. Then here comes this app like, ‚ÄúYou seem rested! Time to step up your game.‚Äù ‚Ä¶Really? 25K steps and yall acting like I didn‚Äôt exercise? Go sit down somewhere. 

Also, I hate the notifications that tell me I burned a banana and an orange or some jawn. It feels super condescending. Just gimme a number.

title: App is good but Well-being  is disappointing

content.text:
Been tracking my health metrics for years with iPhone and Apple Watch SE 2020. 

Wellbeing rolled out today and‚Ä¶.. it says ‚Äúinsufficient data‚Äù because of too much interference (? Radio interference-what does interference mean). And I need to wear it while I sleep. (I have been wearing my Apple Watch since 2020 and tracking my sleep accordingly. 

If I look down it appears there is no oxygen and temp info because my watch doesn‚Äôt support it. 

I‚Äôm left to conclude that Well-being only works with later Apple Watches. If that is the case, why offer it to us who don‚Äôt have the feature and then blame it on interference (whatever interference is).

Bummed

content.text: I‚Äôm always the person to start going 110%, burn myself out, and stop working out for like a month because of it. I absolutely love this app because it‚Äôs finally gotten me back into regularly working out, at a healthy pace, and I feel incredible because I‚Äôm not burning myself out anymore. On top of the fact that the app‚Äôs features work wonders, it‚Äôs incredibly polished- every little button and slider feels great to use- every little thing seems like there was so much attention to detail put into it. The little flashes of colors, the incredible graphs, the little haptics that play when you slide a bar, everything is easy and fun to do. Massive kudos to the design team, from a designer myself.

content.text:
The algorithm they‚Äôre using to determine if you‚Äôre on track or need to rest is very, very basic. Like I think it‚Äôs only looking at duration of the activities I log manually and assuming I‚Äôm pushing myself to the limit.  It was telling me I need to go do something, so I logged the 3 hours of ‚Äúdaily chores‚Äù I did earlier in the day cleaning out the garage, which was in heart rate zone zero and I marked as just a little exertion. And then it said I was waaay overreaching! 

Whether it‚Äôs working as designed or not, I‚Äôm not learning much from this app about my fitness level and if I‚Äôm actually improving anything. It isn‚Äôt any more motivational than a plain old daily reminder.

content.text:
Overall, this app is fantastic. I use it exclusively on my Apple Watch. I have a request, though ‚Äî and I think this is an opportunity Apple missed: I‚Äôd like to be able to cancel or abort a workout. 

I‚Äôm a homebody, and use Gentler Streak to track my morning household chores. But there are occasions where I‚Äôve failed to stop the tracker. The next thing I know, another half hour has passed and I notice the tracker is still running. In those cases, a simple cancel button‚Äî perhaps beneath the ‚ÄúDone‚Äù one, and coupled with a ‚ÄúDo you really want to cancel?‚Äù  prompt ‚Äî could stop the workout BEFORE it writes to the health data? I would much rather lose the 15 minutes of actual activity than keep a 45 minute instance I knew was false ‚Äî I‚Äôd rather close the ring honestly and not have workouts later in the day affected by the mistake. 

Thank you so much!

content.text:
I‚Äôve been enjoying the encouragement notifications the app gives me after my workouts but today I‚Äôm running late and what do I see? A notification saying ‚Äú EXERCISE REMINDER You're about to wave adios to your streak. Start a Go Gentler workout and get back in the game.‚Äù  

Not ok. I don‚Äôt know about other people but my willpower works on POSITIVE reinforcement, not negative. Not wanting to feel like a loser is not a motivation for me. Sometimes I need a day off for very good reasons. Telling me I‚Äôm about to say ‚Äúadios‚Äù to my streak makes me want to skip a day just to spite you. 

Reminders like ‚ÄúYou got this!‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing great, don‚Äôt stop!‚Äù are what will keep me going. This app is so good otherwise and the negativity just seemed surprising. I hope they can update the app to either ditch the negative reinforcement or give us a choice.

Reminders like ‚ÄúYou got this!‚Äù and ‚ÄúYou‚Äôre doing great, don‚Äôt stop!‚Äù are what will keep me going. This app is so good otherwise and the negativity just seemed surprising. I hope they can update the app to either ditch the negative reinforcement or give us a choice.

title: Nifty for fitness, but harmful for womens health info

content.text:
Long story short: The fitness tracking seems good, but the womens health articles read like they‚Äôre written by a quack and shame contraceptive use for cramps. 

The app has seemed good so far, and I find it refreshing that they focus on not just active days, but rest days as well. It could be nice to be able to dig in a little deeper at times to understand how they come to their recommendations for you. I reeeaally don‚Äôt like their Womens Health articles, though. They frame menstrual cramps as if they‚Äôre the woman‚Äôs fault from being too stressed or having a poor diet. Yes, those things can contribute, but menstrual cramping is incredibly common and not just some behavioral issue that would be fixed if we all lived a little healthier. They also state that if you use contraceptives to for these issues, that you should ‚Äúkeep in mind they don‚Äôt really solve hormonal imbalances; they just clog up the symptoms‚Äù. One common cause of menstrual cramping is endometriosis. Endometriosis can be managed and prevented from progressing through the use of hormonal contraceptives. It doesn‚Äôt just ‚Äúclog up the symptoms‚Äù. It‚Äôs a legitimate treatment for many health issues, and the alternative is other hormone treatment or surgery, which is far more invasive. Their description is not just misleading but almost like they‚Äôre shaming people who use contraceptives (or anything ‚Äúsynthetic‚Äù). This could easily be harmful to someone who doesn‚Äôt know much about the topic.

It also suggests alternatives including active recovery or simply taking a rest day. The activity path also adds an extra layer of motivation because I want to see it trend upward. I also really liked that the app was able to pick up my existing activity data and show me a summary of 2022. Thanks for creating such a wonderful app!

title: A very nice app and concept! But‚Ä¶

content.text:
The app‚Äôs concept is lovely! However, if you are a seasoned athlete or advanced fitness fanatic, this is probably not the app for you. As an advanced athlete myself, I find the app constantly thinks I am ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù the healthy progress zone. Normal training for me seems to be overtraining according the activity bar. 

I do enjoy the insights, which is mainly my purpose for using it at this point haha. But this is definitely an app geared more toward those in the beginning and intermediate stages of their fitness journey!

title: Very pleasant interface. Possibly too gentle?

content.text:
I just downloaded the app, and I REALLY enjoy the aesthetic of this application. It is very fun to interact with and I‚Äôm excited to check back in to see how it interprets my data.

I understand this app might be tailored to individuals who are just beginning their wellness/fitness/etc. journeys, but is there a way to raise the ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù limit? Or possibly make the message more supportive? As soon as I plugged in my information Yorhart told me I was overreaching, when actually I‚Äôm feeling pretty enthusiastic about my training and life in general right now.

Or maybe the ‚Äúoverreaching‚Äù limit doesn‚Äôt need to be raised. But users are presented with goal options, and based on what goals we select Yorhart will support us differently?

- ‚ÄúRecovering from an injury? You might be overreaching.‚Äù

- ‚ÄúHey there! Remember if your goal is to balance your personal and professional life, you may be slightly overreaching for your goal.‚Äù

- Or, ‚ÄúHey go getter! Congratulations on exceeding your goal once again! Keep up the hard work and you‚Äôll be setting a new goal before you know it!‚Äù

I hope any of this was worth while, and doesn‚Äôt sound too critical. I really enjoy the app, and even though it is literally called ‚ÄúGentler Streak‚Äù I would just love to see a more supportive message when I‚Äôm feeling like a go getter. There‚Äôs so much potential here. And I will definitely keep using and sharing!

Thank you!

content.text:
This seems like a seriously useful app. It's really got the right idea and the app really seems polished and clean without bugs. Great job on that. 

After using it for a week I notice it says I'm overreaching when I'm definitely not. I feel better than before. And I believe that's due to a couple reasons. It doesn't take into account sleep and it also doesn't take into account untracked activity. One of the missing ingredients here that make this app difficult to trust is that it doesn't tap into the Apple Watches ability to track other metrics in the background. Say I walk 15k steps that day in a bit of an abnormal day (this wasn't intentional exercise and I didn't track it) gentler streak has no idea and is still urging me to hit my target. The inverse is also true, if I have a lot of untracked activity history, gentler streak isn't accounting for that so it's really setting the bar low and telling me I'm constantly over reaching when really, I'm not. 
It also doesn't account for sleep which can also be tracked by a variety of devices and then pulled from apple health. I may sleep really great and be fully recovered but it makes no impact on how much I can do the next day. 

I would also like to know with a little more clarity if I follow the path, will I actually start to increase my fitness? Or will the path always peak me under what I'm capable of? Right now as it's constantly "overreaching" I feel a bit stifled. I know that's the point, but the problem is it tells me I'm pushing hard when I'm definitely not. I would like to feel like I'm actually overreaching when it says it.

title: Finally a workout tracker that makes sense

content.text: I‚Äôve been using this app for about a month now and I absolutely love it. I don‚Äôt feel pushed to workout when my body is worn out. It lets me know when I need to step it up or if what I‚Äôm doing will maintain my current fitness level. It also tells me when I absolutely need a rest or I‚Äôll hurt myself. It‚Äôs simple to use and understand. This is the motivation and guidance I‚Äôve been needing. I have been consistent in my work outs since downloading this app and I feel better about actually working out. I highly recommend trying this app.

I like the graph view of my activity compared to prior days (instead of rings) but I didn‚Äôt find it worth the subscription (or buying the app outright, which I do appreciate the option for!!)

content.text:
First off, I‚Äôm writing this on my iPad cause it‚Äôs lots easier than hunt-peck on the iPhone. I‚Äôm surprised to find the app on the iPad, nonetheless, opening it I discovered I‚Äôd have to go thru the same initial setup routine I did on the iPhone. Yet, without doing it, the app informed me I‚Äôd already subscribed. So why wasn‚Äôt all my data there as well? The app itself is far superior to Apple‚Äôs own. Unlike theirs, this one is more realistic. For example, taking time off, including daily chores in one‚Äôs workout routines. I‚Äôm still unsure subscribing is necessary, nonetheless, I‚Äôm going thru with it because I believe in supporting those who have gone to the trouble to put such a fine app together. I also commend the developers for tying in Apples exercise data. It takes awhile to download it into the app, but there it all is. Improvements such as enlarging the timer on each exercise routine. For some reason, heart rate is the app‚Äôs #1 priority while exercising. Its there in BIG numbers while the timer is stuck in the top left corner in tiny figures. Swimming & not being able to clearly see the elapsed time makes things difficult. Highly recommended for anyone looking for a better exercise app than Apples.

Added Aug 24. Unfortunately, I‚Äôve had to down rate this app due to it‚Äôs swimming choices. I did receive a reply regarding the timer, but her advice is wrong. Instead of moving the timer to the middle screen, it starts a separate timer altogether. When finished, swiping to the left to stop takes quite some time cause the watch doesn‚Äôt like wet fingers. Then, like EVERY exercise routine in Gentler, it takes a VERY HARD press to get the Done screen to appear. Why so much effort??? But the most egregious error is its failure to call up Apples water eject feature wherein we must spin the crown until hearing an audible sound informing us the watch is unlocked. I‚Äôve no idea if water remains or not.  No matter what I do, that eject water feature just does not appear.

content.text: I read a lot about this app and was excited to try it, but during every day of the free trial it told me I was overworked and to take a rest day. Every day! The fact that I‚Äôve had only rest days for a year kind of scares me ‚Äî what body metrics is this thing reading and what is wrong with me?? Well, you can‚Äôt find out on the app or the website what inputs it‚Äôs using to tell you to rest. If it‚Äôs just a calibration problem that would be good transparency to put somewhere in the insights. Otherwise this company is simply withholding information rather than stopping me from being overwhelmed by it.

title: Suggestion and Review: Gentler Streak App

content.text: I have recently started using your app and became immediately attached to it! As a D1 athlete, I use my Apple Watch almost every day when it comes to seeing the number of calories I burnt, the distance I traveled, my average pace, and now my recovery meter! I wanted to make a recommendation for one of the activities on the app: Outdoor Rowing. Currently, the watch face only displays my calories burnt, the amount of time that has gone by, and my average heart rate. I would really like it if there was a way to customize it and see my distance as I row. Some additional features such as my pace, or stroke rate would be a great add-on as well. Overall, I'm super satisfied with the app that your team has created!

title: Helpful to learn to listen to body cues

content.text:
Updated: I‚Äôm blown away by how quickly my concerns about the food emojis being triggering were addressed in the app. I‚Äôm now a subscriber and have updated my rating. Thanks for being so open and responsive!

Old:
Why have a little emoji implying I burned off a slice of pizza during yoga? You seem to get with the whole concept of the app that people need a more supportive way to meet fitness goals, and the food icons just reek of diet culture. Really enough of a turn-off that I uninstalled the app.

content.text: I‚Äôve been using Gentler Streak Premium for about a month, and it‚Äôs been a game changer for both my physical fitness and mental health. I now no longer feel guilty for taking a rest day, in fact now I embrace it! Counterintuitively, my cardio fitness (as measured by my VO2 max) and my strength have improved despite taking more days off. I now realize that I was likely doing too much activity and not resting enough. I‚Äôm working hard to stay in the green, although I still ‚Äúoverreach‚Äù about once a week. So far, I have nothing but good things to say about this app!

It tells me my body is struggling and I should take a few days off. 
So I do. 

Then it tells me my fitness is in decline and I need to work out. 
So I do‚Ä¶. 

Halfway through a workout the app is telling me I need to take a break because my body is struggling ü§Ø

Please make up your mind. 
I‚Äôve been pushing myself at this level of 6 months and have no problem with it. So why does the app think I have a problem?

content.text: Gentler Streak is a perfect complement for the activity rings. It helps guide you into doing more intense exercises or doing light exercises. It helps me not try to take the easy way out and only take walks all week and to actually do an intense exercise when my body is capable of it.

title: Great way to look at health data

content.text:
I love the way the data is presented in this app. It‚Äôs really clear and easy to find and yet includes a lot of information. The layout of this app is excellent and the graphics are great. I love scrolling through and seeing all my workouts in one place and digging deeper to see how I did during those workouts.  

I have always wished Apple had a mechanism for taking a rest day or saying I was sick and taking it easy and this app lets me do that. I love the idea of the activity cloud as a quick way to see how I‚Äôm doing. I wonder though, if it adjusts over time because I signed up at a time when I hadn‚Äôt been super active for a while and now that I‚Äôm going back to my regular routine it thinks I‚Äôm working too hard. 

Overall, I‚Äôm loving this app and I highly recommend it.

title: Great app! Looking forward to seeing it expand!

content.text: Love the layout and the fun information given to match my activity. Keeps me engaged and coming back. Would love a ‚Äúbody battery‚Äù kind of meter and maybe expand into sleep tracking in relation to recovery with HRV and RHR. Basically whoop and garmin it up but keep the same charm. Otherwise as is it‚Äôs leaps and bounds better than what Apple gives stock and I‚Äôd recommend people install this app! Really great job.
